repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This gets a minimal limited API example working with Py_LIMITED_API defined, and adds a small test to prove it.

comment_data.body: The `GET_ITEM` call should rather be guarded by `SAFE_MACROS` and `BORROWED_REFS`.
Same here, we shouldn't unconditionally use the macro.
Isn't there a `NULL` end-marker missing for the arguments?
Ok, that looks expensive. But having it work at all is probably still better than having it fail..

This is the fallback code for "int type is bigger than long long" or "int type is bigger than long and Python doesn't define `PY_LONG_LONG`". So practically I doubt it gets used much.

But yeah, I expect it's expensive.

Still thinking about this. In both cases the `BORROWED_REFS` guard looks hard to implement, and isn't necessary for limited API support (where we allow borrowed refs by default).

So I'd rather just do `SAFE_MACROS` at this stage.

I've moved `__Pyx_PyTuple_GET_SIZE` inside `SAFE_MACROS` but I don't think this is the right solution so may come back and change it.
I think these should now be handled (at the cost of some complication)

This looks like we don't need the string list and could just generate the `#if` guard with two `self.signature.use_fastcall` conditions instead of one. That's how we do this pretty much everywhere else, so maybe this is just an editing artefact?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3880,6 +3877,32 @@ def generate_argument_parsing_code(self, env, code):
                 if not arg.type.create_from_py_utility_code(env):
                     pass  # will fail later
 
+        # Assign nargs variable as len(args).
+        if self.signature_has_generic_args():
+            nargs_code = [
+                "#if CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS",
+                "%s = PyTuple_GET_SIZE(%s);" % (
+                        Naming.nargs_cname, Naming.args_cname),
+                "#else",
+                "%s = PyTuple_Size(%s);" % (
+                        Naming.nargs_cname, Naming.args_cname),
+                code.error_goto_if_neg(Naming.nargs_cname, self.pos),
+                "#endif",
+            ]
+            if self.signature.use_fastcall:
+                code.putln("#if !CYTHON_METH_FASTCALL")
+                for line in nargs_code:
+                    code.putln(line)
+                code.putln("#endif")
+            else:
+                for line in nargs_code:
+                    code.putln(line)

comment_data.body: I wonder if we should really look at `Py_VERSION_HEX` here or the requested Limited API version. (And I wonder if that doesn't generally apply in all Limited API sections…)
I'll just ignore this part in my review and believe both properties as you state them here.
Does this look any better if you reverse the conditions to put `#if AVOID_BORROWED_REFS` first and `#if SAFE_MACROS` second?

Isn't this guard the wrong way round? And, should we really keep the two borrowed references around for so long below? We might want to incref both any way, don't you think? At least if the fast pointer comparison below fails and we need to do actual comparisons. I don't think those are always safe while holding on to borrowed references.
Seems worth reversing the two cases.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -414,7 +450,20 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 // (because it's an old version of CPython or it's not CPython at all),
 // then the ..._FASTCALL macros simply alias ..._VARARGS
 
-#define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GET_ITEM(args, i)
+#if CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS && !CYTHON_AVOID_BORROWED_REFS
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GET_ITEM(args, i)
+#elif !CYTHON_AVOID_BORROWED_REFS
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GetItem(args, i)
+#else
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PySequence_GetItem(args, i)
+#endif
+#if !CYTHON_AVOID_BORROWED_REFS
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_NEWREF(arg) arg // no-op
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_XDECREF_VARARGS(arg) // no-op - arg is borrowed
+#else
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_NEWREF(arg) __Pyx_NewRef(arg)
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_XDECREF_VARARGS(arg) Py_XDECREF(arg)
+#endif

comment_data.body: Weren't macros with `...` arguments an issue in C89? I faintly recall that this was a gcc extension at the time.
You're right - I've fixed this by getting code object generation to work on the limited API rather than reformatting the macro.

The guard was definitely the wrong way round. I've changed it so key and value are universally reference counted in this function to avoid having to think too much about what's safe. (So now there's no guard)

In this particular case `(struct _frame*)` looks to work on all Python versions so I've removed the condition.

In general you're right - we usually want to use the limited API version in Limited API sections (I've exposed that with a `__PYX_LIMITED_VERSION_HEX` which will be `PY_VERSION_HEX` in non-limited API mode). Here we did want to use `PY_VERSION_HEX` but that's probably a defect in CPython really.

BTW, `PY_LONG_LONG` is now always defined in recent CPython versions. I think since back when they switched to C99 or a bit later, when they noticed that their code actually doesn't compile without `HAVE_LONG_LONG` any more. :)

It does look like it would slow down exception propagation considerably, though. We can probably cache the code object (or its `replace` method) and just run that each time, rather than also creating a fresh one (i.e. two) for each traceback frame.

I'd be ok with keeping it as it is for now, and apply optimisations later. Let's just keep in mind that this is probably not final.

Let's keep the order the same as for the decref macros below. We could even merge the two blocks since the definitions belong together, really.
```suggestion
#if CYTHON_AVOID_BORROWED_REFS
    // This is the only case where we request an owned reference.
    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PySequence_GetItem(args, i)
#elif CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS
    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GET_ITEM(args, i)
#else
    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GetItem(args, i)
#endif
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -414,7 +456,20 @@ static int __Pyx_MergeKeywords(PyObject *kwdict, PyObject *source_mapping) {
 // (because it's an old version of CPython or it's not CPython at all),
 // then the ..._FASTCALL macros simply alias ..._VARARGS
 
-#define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GET_ITEM(args, i)
+#if CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS && !CYTHON_AVOID_BORROWED_REFS
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GET_ITEM(args, i)
+#elif !CYTHON_AVOID_BORROWED_REFS
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PyTuple_GetItem(args, i)
+#else
+    #define __Pyx_Arg_VARARGS(args, i) PySequence_GetItem(args, i)
+#endif

comment_data.body:
This also looks really slow, given that we'd do this on each method lookup. It's ok to get it working this way, but I doubt that it can stay that way.

In general, we should try not to be visibly slower than CPython, at least on stuff that happens repeatedly. We can assume that users of the Limited API do not care as much about performance as others, but they'd probably still not want their code to run much slower than in plain Python.
The `.replace()` method was only added in Py3.8 and is missing in Py3.7.

I've added a really lazy workaround for Py3.7 (essentially just using `eval`). I doubt its performance is great, but given we're dropping support for Python 3.7 fairly soon I think I can live with that (and I really didn't want to write the C code myself).

If someone else wants to improve it they can!

It might be worth double checking if we actually use this. I think it's mainly used in CythonFunction.c, which has been rewritten substantially for the limited API anyway, so it's possible that we can just drop this.

Yeah - it'd noticed that it could be cached, but was just trying to keep things simple for the initial version.

We can definitely come back and optimize this later.

I'm also open to different approaches, but I honestly couldn't think of anything else that might work.
I've also refactored this slightly again, since it used `replace` and so was also broken on Py3.7. Might be a bit more performant than before, but probably relies on somewhat unstable (Python) API
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -641,71 +649,125 @@ class __Pyx_FakeReference {
 #else
   #define __Pyx_BUILTIN_MODULE_NAME "builtins"
   #define __Pyx_DefaultClassType PyType_Type
-#if PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030B00A1
-    static CYTHON_INLINE PyCodeObject* __Pyx_PyCode_New(int a, int p, int k, int l, int s, int f,
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
+    // Note that the limited API doesn't know about PyCodeObject, so the type of this
+    // is PyObject (unlike for the main API)
+    static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyCode_New(int a, int p, int k, int l, int s, int f,

comment_data.body:
I think these would be better read from `inspect` when the module is initialized (i.e. much like the debug flag) - it feels a bit against the spirit of the limited API to just redefine constants that have been intentionally excluded.

With that said, I'll create an issue when this PR is done rather than try to make too many more changes.

commit.message:
Get a some of the limited API working with Py_LIMITED_API defined

This gets a minimal limited API example working with Py_LIMITED_API
defined, and adds a small test to prove it.
Make arg spliting code handle avoid borrowed references
Reorder imports to allow monkey patching
Fix syntax error in regular mode
ITEM and GetItem were the wrong way round

Changes CyFunction to compile with Py_LIMITED_API

Mostly that we store the PyCFunctionObject as an attribute of
it rather than "inheriting" from PyCFunctionObject.

commit.message: Minimal change to get classes working
Comments from review; get code working

Fix code on Py3.11 and Py3.12

The documentation lied...
Adapt to awkward arg naming change
Let's avoid owned reference at least for the very common and safe fast path.
